prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in engineering would.
problem_prompt:
Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in engineering would. Compute
\[\frac{\sin 13^\circ + \sin 47^\circ + \sin 73^\circ + \sin 107^\circ}{\cos 17^\circ}.\]
gpt_response:
We recognize that the numerator can be written as the real part of the sum of the complex numbers \(e^{i 13^\circ} + e^{i 47^\circ} + e^{i 73^\circ} + e^{i 107^\circ}\). Using Euler's formula, this becomes
\[\frac{\text{Re}\left(e^{i 13^\circ} + e^{i 47^\circ} + e^{i 73^\circ} + e^{i 107^\circ}\right)}{\cos 17^\circ} = \frac{\text{Re}\left(e^{i \pi/15} + e^{i 7\pi/15} + e^{i 13\pi/15} + e^{i 17\pi/15}\right)}{\cos 17^\circ} = \frac{\cos \frac{\pi}{15} + \cos \frac{7\pi}{15} + \cos \frac{13\pi}{15} + \cos \frac{17\pi}{15}}{\cos 17^\circ}.\]Using the sum-to-product identities, we get
\[\frac{\cos \frac{\pi}{15} + \cos \frac{7\pi}{15} + \cos \frac{13\pi}{15} + \cos \frac{17\pi}{15}}{\cos 17^\circ} = \frac{2 \cos \frac{8\pi}{15} \cos \frac{\pi}{15} + 2 \cos \frac{8\pi}{15} \cos \frac{5\pi}{15}}{\cos 17^\circ} = \frac{2\cos \frac{8\pi}{15} (\cos \frac{\pi}{15} + \cos \frac{5\pi}{15})}{\cos 17^\circ} = \frac{2\cos \frac{8\pi}{15} (2\cos \frac{\pi}{3} \cos \frac{2\pi}{15})}{\cos 17^\circ} = \frac{2\cos \frac{8\pi}{15}(\cos \frac{2\pi}{3})}{\cos 17^\circ} = \frac{2\cos \frac{8\pi}{15}(-\frac{1}{2})}{\cos 17^\circ} = -\cos \frac{8\pi}{15} = \boxed{-\frac{\sqrt{30} - \sqrt{6}}{8}}.\]
solution_prompt:
The following is a response to a question. Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following response 3?: We recognize that the numerator can be written as the real part of the sum of the complex numbers \(e^{i 13^\circ} + e^{i 47^\circ} + e^{i 73^\circ} + e^{i 107^\circ}\). Using Euler's formula, this becomes
\[\frac{\text{Re}\left(e^{i 13^\circ} + e^{i 47^\circ} + e^{i 73^\circ} + e^{i 107^\circ}\right)}{\cos 17^\circ} = \frac{\text{Re}\left(e^{i \pi/15} + e^{i 7\pi/15} + e^{i 13\pi/15} + e^{i 17\pi/15}\right)}{\cos 17^\circ} = \frac{\cos \frac{\pi}{15} + \cos \frac{7\pi}{15} + \cos \frac{13\pi}{15} + \cos \frac{17\pi}{15}}{\cos 17^\circ}.\]Using the sum-to-product identities, we get
\[\frac{\cos \frac{\pi}{15} + \cos \frac{7\pi}{15} + \cos \frac{13\pi}{15} + \cos \frac{17\pi}{15}}{\cos 17^\circ} = \frac{2 \cos \frac{8\pi}{15} \cos \frac{\pi}{15} + 2 \cos \frac{8\pi}{15} \cos \frac{5\pi}{15}}{\cos 17^\circ} = \frac{2\cos \frac{8\pi}{15} (\cos \frac{\pi}{15} + \cos \frac{5\pi}{15})}{\cos 17^\circ} = \frac{2\cos \frac{8\pi}{15} (2\cos \frac{\pi}{3} \cos \frac{2\pi}{15})}{\cos 17^\circ} = \frac{2\cos \frac{8\pi}{15}(\cos \frac{2\pi}{3})}{\cos 17^\circ} = \frac{2\cos \frac{8\pi}{15}(-\frac{1}{2})}{\cos 17^\circ} = -\cos \frac{8\pi}{15} = \boxed{-\frac{\sqrt{30} - \sqrt{6}}{8}}.\]
